qas.question: Whose publications started the theory of Natural phonology?
According to Stampe what is phonology based on?

answers.text: a set of universal phonological processes

qas.question: Aside from being active what other condition can the universal phonological processes exist in?
Who is the number two natural phonologist?
Who was the founder of natural morphology?
Whose publications started the theory of universal input?

plausible_answers.text: a set of universal phonological processes

qas.question: According to Stampe what is universal input based on?
Aside from being active what other condition can the natural morphology exist in?
Who is the number two universal processor?
Who was the founder of active utterance?

context: Natural phonology is a theory based on the publications of its proponent <a0_0><b5_0>David Stampe<b5_0/><a0_0/> in 1969 and (more explicitly) in 1979. In this view, phonology is based on <a1_0><b6_0>a set of universal phonological processes<b6_0/><a1_0/> that interact with one another; which ones are active and which are <a2_0><b7_0>suppressed<b7_0/><a2_0/> is language-specific. Rather than acting on segments, phonological processes act on distinctive features within prosodic groups. Prosodic groups can be as small as a part of a syllable or as large as an entire utterance. Phonological processes are unordered with respect to each other and apply simultaneously (though the output of one process may be the input to another). The second most prominent natural phonologist is <a3_0><b8_0>Patricia Donegan<b8_0/><a3_0/> (Stampe's wife); there are many natural phonologists in Europe, and a few in the U.S., such as Geoffrey Nathan. The principles of natural phonology were extended to morphology by <a4_0><b9_0>Wolfgang U. Dressler<b9_0/><a4_0/>, who founded natural morphology.
